If this is truly an error, then why are we just logging instead of throwing the error back to the user?

@mjsax You also mentioned that we may want to add a `windowed` serde in `Serdes.java`, right?

Also that part may need some careful thought as the `WindowedSerde` still need an internal `Serde` and how to specify that in the `Serdes` factory is tricky.
Yeah I think throwing the exception is preferable if we have agreed that this should really be a fatal error.
@ewencp please review.
This only changes the system test utility for Connect, so it'd be great to backport this to 0.11.0 to fix the current failures with most of the Connect system tests running against packaged Kafka.

@dbtucker @hachikuji @gwenshap Pretty simple fix. I tested by adding

```
transforms=hoist,timestamp,convert
transforms.hoist.type=org.apache.kafka.connect.transforms.HoistField$Value
transforms.hoist.field=value
transforms.timestamp.type=org.apache.kafka.connect.transforms.InsertField$Value
transforms.timestamp.timestamp.field=timestamp
transforms.convert.type=org.apache.kafka.connect.transforms.TimestampConverter$Value
transforms.convert.field=timestamp
transforms.convert.target.type=string
transforms.convert.format=yyyy MM dd HH mm ss SSS z
```

to the file source connector and inspecting the results and things work fine (though I wouldn't mind some additional verification). At some point we'll probably want some integration tests to be able to validate things like this end-to-end, but I added unit tests for all the transformations to validate that they at least don't have any obvious conflicts that would be caught just be creating the ConnectorConfig extended with the transformations.

System test passed: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/328/
(seems you need to schedule a new build -- rerunning a failed one after a rebase seems to use the old version and does not pick up the change)
Merging to trunk and 0.11.0.

Just double checked the JIRA. Yes, having `WindowedSerde` would be idea. As it should be type agnostic, user would need to inherit from it I guess to have a generics free `UserWindowSerde` -- thus `WindowSerde` should also be abstract. We can add a usage pattern example in the JavaDocs. Does this make sense (please correct me, did not think about it in detail...)
LGTM

@ijuma Agreed, can we tell just based on the Jenkins runtime or is that too variable based on which slave it runs on?

Was talking with @cmccabe and it was suggested annoying output options might have been the reason for not enabling the output. I don't think this is a problem since we don't print the std streams by default anyway, though it might affect people who test locally with those enabled (and do we have them enabled on Jenkins?).
@mjsax @apurvam @hachikuji @sriramsub for reviews.

@ewencp https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-branch-builder/ is pretty reliable. I started a build on your branch. We can then do one for trunk and compare (seems like the tasks are a little different to the main job, so probably worth doing 2 runs in the branch builder).

I think we can try this and if it turns out to be annoying for some, we can tweak it. Better than keeping things as they are because of the possibility that someone had a good reason years ago. :)

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5318/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

Hmm, I don't think the changes in this PR do anything. Random ports are used by default by `KafkaServerTestHarness` and `clearing` the lists should not have any effect since `close()` had already been called.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5319/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

I looked at the code, and the `IntegrationTestHarness` explicitly uses the `TestUtil.RandomPort`, but the `KafkaServerTestHarness` does not. The config printed on the console before this patch showed that port 9092 was being used by the kafka server. 

Regarding close(), that is puzzling. Indeed, close is being called, but a bunch of test cases use the producer instance at the head of the queue. If it's the same instance as used in a previous test, the `TransactionState` will not be `UNINITIALIZED`, which can create invalid transition state errors.
retest this please

These are all longshot hypothesis. I'll let this and PR https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3345 a run a few times. If one fails more than the other, we will have more information. The other PR already hit cases which suggest that these are problems 33% of the time so far.

A couple of things:
1. I was a bit imprecise. KafkaServerTestHarness doesn't do the configs. However, your test (and most other tests), call `TestUtils.createBrokerConfigs` that eventually calls:

```scala
def createBrokerConfig(nodeId: Int, zkConnect: String,
    enableControlledShutdown: Boolean = true,
    enableDeleteTopic: Boolean = false,
    port: Int = RandomPort,
    interBrokerSecurityProtocol: Option[SecurityProtocol] = None,
    trustStoreFile: Option[File] = None,
    saslProperties: Option[Properties] = None,
    enablePlaintext: Boolean = true,
    enableSaslPlaintext: Boolean = false, saslPlaintextPort: Int = RandomPort,
    enableSsl: Boolean = false, sslPort: Int = RandomPort,
    enableSaslSsl: Boolean = false, saslSslPort: Int = RandomPort, rack: Option[String] = None)
  : Properties = {
```

2. A new instance of the class is created for each test run, so clearing the list should have no effect.
If you saw that port 9092 was being used, then it would be good to understand how that happened.

Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).
Hmm. it seems the printed config has some bug. THe ports for all the 3 servers in the test was 9092, which should not be possible.

I guess this are the relevant config lines: 
```
	listener.security.protocol.map = PLAINTEXT:PLAINTEXT
	listeners = PLAINTEXT://localhost:0
```

and not: 

```
	port = 9092
```

That would explain it.
@apurvam that's right.

This was my bad. Got excited because it seemed to explain the symptoms. In fact, I think we can take the ProducerFencedException out of the picture. It's confusing because jenkins seems to combine the log messages from multiple test cases, but if you look at the timeline to see when each test was started, the ProducerFencedException was being thrown from one of the fencing tests:

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-jdk8/1701/testReport/kafka.api/TransactionsTest/testDelayedFetchIncludesAbortedTransaction/.

So that leaves us with this exception and the fact that the read_uncommitted consumer timed out trying to consume all 8 records:

```
org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: Invalid transition attempted from state READY to state ABORTABLE_ERROR
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.TransactionManager.transitionTo(TransactionManager.java:477)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.TransactionManager.transitionToAbortableError(TransactionManager.java:289)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.failBatch(Sender.java:601)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.sendProducerData(Sender.java:272)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.run(Sender.java:223)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.Sender.run(Sender.java:162)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
```

Retest this please
#3345 failed on `kafka.api.TransactionsTest.testReadCommittedConsumerShouldNotSeeUndecidedData` with the similar output.

I noticed one bug in `RecordAccumulator` which _might_ explain the problem. The issue is this line: https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/internals/RecordAccumulator.java#L584. We should be holding a lock when we call `isEmpty()`. If this call had returned true incorrectly, then we would have proceeded to send the COMMIT and only afterwards would the batches be sent. This could cause us to transition to READY with produce requests still in progress. If those requests failed, then we might attempt to transition to ABORTABLE_ERROR when they return. I'm not totally sure that the sequence is possible, but might be worth fixing just to rule it out.

Hmm, @ijuma it looks like the difference in execution time is non-trivial 21.5 min with all logging disabled vs 27.5 min with that patch. Unfortunately it will probably take some experimentation to figure out which of the changes has the most impact (if any of them even dominate).
@ewencp if I had to guess, it would be the request logging. Maybe this is an acceptable increase given that we are increasing testing coverage.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5328/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

@ijuma Maybe, but we could also potentially be more targeted -- I was hoping we could effectively get it for free. I don't know log4j that well, but it should probably be possible to turn that logging on for one targeted test. I tried that initially but was looking for a quick solution and switched to this when it didn't work at first. Probably worth looking into a bit more before accepting a nearly 30% hit it testing time.
